statement.tex: %text Using properties of definite integrals, evaluate the following \[ \qquad \qquad \int_0^\pi\dfrac{x\cdot\tan x}{\sec x + \tan x} \cdot dx \] %
\\ %text \underline{\text{Are we right}} in saying the following? %
\\ %text Given that \[2A = \pi\int_0^\pi\dfrac{\sin x}{1+\sin x}\cdot dx \], \underline{\text{which of the following is true}}? %

\\ %text What will $A_2$ be in the integral below? And therefore, what will be the \underline\text{value of A}?
\[ \qquad 2A = \pi\left[\pi-\underbrace{\frac{1}{2}\int_0^\pi\sec^2\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{x}{2}\right)\cdot dx}_{A_2}\right]\] %

reason.tex: \begin{align} 2A &= \pi\int_0^\pi\dfrac{1+\sin x-1}{1+\sin x}\cdot dx \\ &=\pi\int_0^\pi\left[1-\dfrac{1}{1+\sin x}\right]\cdot dx \\ &= \pi\left[\int_0^\pi dx -\int_0^\pi\dfrac{1}{1+\sin x}\cdot dx\right] \\ &= \pi\left[\pi - \int_0^\pi\dfrac{1}{\underbrace{1+\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-x\right)}_{\sin x = \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-x\right)}}\cdot dx\right] \\ &= \pi\left[\pi - \underbrace{\frac{1}{2}\int_0^\pi\sec^2\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{x}{2}\right)\cdot dx}_ {\frac{1}{1+\cos\theta} = \frac{1}{2\cos^2\frac{\theta}{2}} = \frac{\sec^2\theta}{2}}\right] \end{align}

\begin{align} A_2 &= \dfrac{1}{2}\int_0^\pi\sec^2\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{x}{2}\right)cdot dx \\ \text{Let } z &= \frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{x}{2}\implies dx = 2\cdot dz \\ \text{Also } z &= \frac{\pi}{4}\text{ when }x =0\text{ and } z = -\frac{\pi}{4}\text{ when }x=\pi\\ \therefore A_2 &= -\frac{2}{2}\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{-\frac{\pi}{4}}\sec^2 z\cdot dz \\ &= -\left[\tan z\right]_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{-\frac{\pi}{4}} = -\left[-1-1\right] = 2 \\ \therefore 2A &= \pi\left[\pi - A_2\right] = \pi\cdot(\pi - 2) \\ \implies A &= \dfrac{\pi}{2}\cdot \left(\pi -2\right) \end{align}
